results.title: Lifetimes of change: development and growth
results.creator_credit: Australian Academy of Science and Educational Media International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Web of life”.
Shows the changes that take place within the lifetimes of individual organisms. Illustrates the ideas of birth, growth, change and decay by using three examples from the natural world: toadstools, frogs and flowering plants. Also notes the main changes in structure and in behaviour that distinguish a human lifetime. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Lifetime employment
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Oliver Howes and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Manufactured exports are basic to Japan’s survival. Conditions of industrial employment are shown particularly in the automotive industry.

results.title: Lifesaving
results.brief_description: This film demonstrates the swimming strokes best adapted to life-saving: how to approach a swimmer in difficulties, breaking holds, carries, methods of rescuing by boat and by ring buoy, and the Schafer method of resuscitation.

results.title: Lifesaving
results.brief_description: This film, which includes a demonstration of land drill by the Southsea Police Lifeguard Corps (England), shows in detail the various methods needed for rescuing a docile person, a turbulent person, somebody really violent, and a tired but clear-headed swimmer. The sidestroke method of rescue, the surface dive necessary if the subject has sunk, and the use of artificial respiration are also demonstrated.
results.description: This film, which includes a demonstration of land drill by the Southsea Police Lifeguard Corps (England), shows in detail the various methods needed for rescuing a docile person, a turbulent person, somebody really violent, and a tired but clear-headed swimmer. results.title: Lifeclimb
results.creator_credit: Stan Zundell, Stan Zundell Productions and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: A documentary in which 64 year old Stan Zundell describes the manner in which he has faced the difficulties and challenges of aging. Shows how he continually challenges himself with rigorous physical activity, increasing his abilities as he struggles to achieve his goals.

results.title: Life: What a Ride
results.brief_description: A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Journeys with Breast Cancer” Created in association with Breast Cancer Network Australia. ” Cancer returns to my body. My breasts are gone, breasts that nurtured four children and gave pleasure. In their place a tapestry of the scars and wounds of the last 12 years.”

results.title: Life. Be in it
results.creator_credit: Victorian Department of Youth, Sport and Recreation
results.brief_description: Phillip Adams conceived and developed the “Life Be In It” advertising campaign aimed at encouraging the community to become more involved in physical activity and recreation. Includes examples of television commercials featuring characters such as Norm, the average all-round armchair sportsman.

results.title: Life with junior
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “March of Time”.
A typical day in the life of a ten-year-old, presenting such common problems as the acceptance of a new brother and the refusal to eat. Emphasises the anxieties of parents over guiding their children in today’s world, and explains ways in which to cope with behaviour problems.

results.title: Life with grandpa
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “March of Time”.
The problems of old age as they affect people in the United States - achievements of medical science in forestalling disease, controlling dangerous ailments earlier in life; with a longer life expectancy, an increasing population of old people; ways of combating prejudices against employing old persons. Some notable personalities of advanced years including Sir Winston Churchill, Dorothy Dix and George Bernard Shaw.
